subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Maps in Quikscript
msgSnippet: Paul: I notice from your e-mail address that you must be a euphonium player. I played the baritone in high school and college.  More recently, I acquired a
messageBody:
Paul:

I notice from your e-mail address that you must be a euphonium player.
I played the baritone in high school and college. More recently, I
acquired a trombone and have played it from time to time.

I took a look at your map, and I like the idea. I would ask this,
however: I see a number of state names that are not spelled the way I
would spell them, and I don't know whether that is due to your
pronunciation of the words being different from mine, or whether they
are simply mistakes in applying QS to them.

As an example, I pronounce /Florida/ with a schwa after the "r". The
online Merriam-Webster dictionary agrees with me. You left the vowel
out after the "r." You wrote what would be in TO /Florda./ Perhaps in
speech you may pronounce it that way, but I have seen it suggested that
we should spell as if the word were emphasized rather than spelling in
accordance with the slovenly way we frequently pronounce words in the
middle of a sentence. Otherwise, you would have internal vowels
disappearing all over the place along with other peculiarities caused by
the words before or after the word in question.

Another example: I pronounce the states with "north" and "south" in
their names with an unvoiced "th" sound, not voiced as you suggested.
Merriam-Websters' pronunciation key does not distinguish between these
two sounds, but the spoken version clearly sounds like what I would
write rather than the voiced version as you put on your map.

I have not taken the time to look at all the state names, but I would
suggest that you check the Merriam-Webster dictionary and revise your
state name spellings to match their pronunciations.

Paige

Paul wrote:
>
> Hello fellow Quikscript afficionados,
>
> I think it would be a good idea to have maps written in Quikscript.
> It'd be a good learning tool because everyone would already know the
> names of various states, provinces, etc. and this would allow faster
> learning of the alphabet.
>
> I'm almost done with a map of the United States and will provide the
> file once I'm done.
>
> Also, the pronunciation will be consistent with that of the General
> American accent for any maps I provide. I have no problem whatsoever
> with maps of the United Kingdom having British pronunciation, maps of
> Canada having Canadian pronunciation, etc. In fact, I think it would
> be best if the regional differences were made manifest in the maps
> pertaining to them.
>
> Thoughts or comments would be greatly appreciated.
>
> -Paul
>
>

I notice from your e-mail address that you must be a euphonium player.  
I played the baritone in high school and college.  More recently, I

Another example:  I pronounce the states with "north" and "south" in
